sources.title: South Carolina Department of Labor, Licensing and Regulation

nonCompete.detailedExplanation: South Carolina enforces reasonable non-compete agreements protecting legitimate business interests. Courts apply reasonableness test for time, geography, and scope. Typically 2 years or less is reasonable. Blue-pencil doctrine applies.
nonCompete.suggestion: Keep duration to 2 years, reasonable geographic scope tied to business territory
nonCompete.actionRequired: Ensure reasonableness in time, geography, and scope
nonCompete.alternativeLanguage: reasonable non-compete restrictions for up to 2 years within [specific geographic area]

salaryHistory.detailedExplanation: South Carolina has no state law prohibiting salary history questions
salaryHistory.bestPractice: Consider avoiding to promote pay equity

payTransparency.message: NO pay transparency or salary disclosure requirements
payTransparency.detailedExplanation: South Carolina does not require salary range disclosure in job postings

backgroundChecks.message: Background checks permitted at any stage - NO ban-the-box law
backgroundChecks.detailedExplanation: South Carolina has no statewide ban-the-box restrictions. Criminal history can be inquired about on applications. Must comply with federal FCRA requirements.
process: Provide pre-adverse action notice if issues found
backgroundChecks.bestPractice: Consider individualized assessment even if not legally required

drugScreening.detailedExplanation: South Carolina allows and encourages drug testing. Employers with certified drug-free workplace programs receive workers' compensation premium discounts (up to 5%).
drugScreening.suggestion: Drug testing is legal and provides workers' comp premium discounts
drugScreening.bestPractice: Consider establishing certified drug-free workplace program for discounts

arbitration.detailedExplanation: South Carolina follows the Federal Arbitration Act. Mandatory arbitration clauses are generally enforceable if not unconscionable.
arbitration.suggestion: Arbitration agreements are acceptable and enforceable
arbitration.bestPractice: Include provisions for reasonable costs and neutral arbitrators
arbitration.source: FAA and South Carolina case law

atWill.detailedExplanation: South Carolina is a strong at-will employment state with very limited exceptions. Employment is presumed at-will unless modified by clear contract.
atWill.bestPractice: Include clear at-will disclaimer to maximize protection
atWill.suggestion: Strong at-will language is legally protective and recommended

minimumWage.message: NO state minimum wage - federal $7.25/hour applies
minimumWage.detailedExplanation: South Carolina has no state minimum wage law. Federal minimum wage of $7.25/hour applies under FLSA.
minimumWage.requirement: Must meet federal minimum wage of $7.25/hour
minimumWage.actionRequired: Ensure compliance with federal minimum wage

paidLeave.message: NO state-mandated paid sick leave or paid family leave
paidLeave.detailedExplanation: South Carolina does not require employers to provide paid sick leave, paid family leave, or vacation time. Federal FMLA may apply for eligible employers (50+ employees).
paidLeave.actionRequired: No state requirements - federal FMLA only for eligible employers
paidLeave.bestPractice: Consider offering paid leave as competitive benefit

finalPay.lawReference: South Carolina Payment of Wages Act
finalPay.message: Final paycheck due within 48 hours or next payday
finalPay.detailedExplanation: Employers must pay final wages either within 48 hours of termination/resignation or by the next regular payday, whichever is later. Some exceptions apply.
finalPay.requirement: Pay within 48 hours or next payday

rightToWork.message: South Carolina is a RIGHT TO WORK state
rightToWork.detailedExplanation: Employees cannot be required to join or pay dues to a union as a condition of employment. Union membership and dues payment must be voluntary.
rightToWork.actionRequired: Cannot require union membership or dues payment
rightToWork.source: South Carolina Right to Work Law

breaks.message: NO required meal or rest breaks for adults
breaks.detailedExplanation: South Carolina does not require employers to provide meal breaks or rest breaks to adult employees. Federal law requires breaks under 20 minutes be paid if provided.
breaks.bestPractice: Consider providing breaks for employee wellbeing and productivity

paymentOfWages.lawReference: South Carolina Payment of Wages Act
paymentOfWages.message: Must establish regular paydays and notify employees
paymentOfWages.detailedExplanation: Employers must establish regular paydays and notify employees of payday, pay rate, and deductions. Wages must be paid at least monthly on regularly scheduled paydays.
paymentOfWages.requirement: Pay at least monthly on regular schedule
paymentOfWages.actionRequired: Establish and communicate regular pay schedule
paymentOfWages.source: South Carolina Payment of Wages Act
